## **Not Just a Book on Media: Extending _The Gutenberg Galaxy_**

ELENA LAMBERTI

### **What was _THAT_? McLuhan’s _Little Point_**

In Henry James’s novella _The Figure in the Carpet_ , Hugh Vereker, a renowned
writer, tells the narrator (himself a writer who has just published a review
of Vereker’s last novel) that all his critics have missed his “little point”:
“By my little point I mean – what shall I call it? – the particular thing I’ve
written my books most FOR. Isn’t there for every writer a particular thing of
that sort, the thing that most makes him apply himself, the thing without the
effort to achieve which he wouldn’t write at all, the very passion of his
passion, the part of the business in which, for him, the flame of art burns
most intensely? Well, it’s THAT!”[1](fm02.html#fm02en1a) The “thing for the
critic to find,” insists Vereker, is “like a complex figure in a Persian
carpet,” but he firmly refuses to tell the puzzled narrator what that figure
looks like: he has to find it for himself. Tormented by the new challenge, the
narrator starts his own search to no avail; he shares this puzzle with his
friend George Corvick who, instead, solves the mystery during a long trip to
India and wires his fiancée, Gwendolyne, “Eureka. Immense,” without saying
“what it is.” His secret discovery will be revealed only to Gwendolyne after
they marry; a secret that Gwendolyne herself will preserve after her husband’s
premature death. Neither her second husband nor the narrator will ever be told
“what it is,” and they will both be left with their suspended curiosity after
Gwendolyne’s own death.

In 1996, when reading _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ for the first time, I felt like
the narrator in James’s novella: it was an unusual, fascinating book, though I
could not _understand_ most of it, it nevertheless _resounded through_ me. The
more I read it, the more it echoed in my mind: I knew that there was something
“particular” in McLuhan’s writing, but I continued to miss his “little point,”
I could not see his “figure in the carpet.” It was only several weeks later,
while reading _The Interior Landscape: The Literary Criticism of Marshall
McLuhan_ ,[2](fm02.html#fm02en2a) that I could shift to George Corvick’s
perspective and say: “Eureka. Immense.” Reading McLuhan’s literary criticism
not only helped me to better understand the work of my favourite modernist
masters (James Joyce, Wyndham Lewis, Ezra Pound are among those discussed in
that book), but it also helped me to better understand “what IT was” in _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ : while reading their fiction and poetry, McLuhan had also
started to read _through_ the modernists’ experiments with language and form;
he had, in fact, _put them on_. He had so fully grasped their literary
implications that he had used them to elaborate his own “particular thing,”
his own form of writing: the _mosaic_. Well, it’s _THAT_!

When reading McLuhan, _form_ is as important as _content_ , just as it is when
we read Joyce, Pound, Lewis, or Eliot. Translating THAT into McLuhanese we
could say that **THE MEDIUM IS THE MESSAGE**. As a literary and a modernist
scholar, for me it was a true epiphany to better understand McLuhan’s form of
writing, and through that, to better appreciate his teachings on literature as
well as on “media as environment”; it was an even greater epiphany to realize
that those same teachings had solid roots in his humanistic background. It is
as simple as that, but it is often neglected or dismissed as a _semantic
leitmotif_ or a _semantic cliché_ when acknowledging McLuhan’s years at
Cambridge University, UK, in the 1930s.[3](fm02.html#fm02en3a) We assume that
he was a well-read man of letters, but we tend to overlook what that implies
and how that shaped his way of being a media scholar. After all, McLuhan
himself used to repeat that “**WATER IS UNKNOWN TO A FISH UNTIL IT DISCOVERS
AIR**.”

Literature and the arts constitute a sort of constant _fil rouge_ , a constant
unspooling thread, connecting in time McLuhan’s media explorations; they are
not used as decorative elements of his grand narrative on media but are,
instead, a structural component of Marshall McLuhan’s original “poetics.” _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ is the perfect case in point: the Homeric tradition is
quoted at the very beginning of the prologue to discuss the interplay of
contrasted cultures, and the works of Milman Parry and Albert B. Lord are
turned into the underpinning subtexts guiding readers on how the Western world
shifted from orality to literacy first, then from literacy to post-literacy.
Following a similar pattern, the first chapter begins with a discussion of
Shakespeare’s _King Lear_ to epitomize the making of Gutenberg’s “fragmented
man”; the same book, _King Lear_ , is then used in the following chapters as a
“working model” enlightening on cultural processes. And many other literary
texts are quoted all through _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ with the same intent.
Consistently, the very last chapter – “The Galaxy Reconfigured” – ends with a
tremendous literary phantasmagoria which evolves into an imaginative
_progression d’effet_ as the reader is asked to confront as many diverse
writers as: Blake, Pope, Ruskin, Rimbaud, Proust, Joyce, Mallarme, Coleridge,
Dryden, Swift, Addison, Steele, Dr Johnson, Poe, Baudelaire, Valéry, Eliot.
Even the very last paragraph of that very last chapter can be read in the
light of a very popular literary tradition, that of the serial novel, as
McLuhan introduces an idea which he promises to further discuss in another
volume. He tells his readers that his story is to be continued and even
announces the title of the next instalment of his “saga”: _Understanding
Media_ ,[4](fm02.html#fm02en4a) which in fact would be published two years
later. Literature is therefore functional to the construction of McLuhan’s
investigative strategy _and_ storytelling, and _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ embeds
an idea that McLuhan had expressed to Walter J. Ong in a letter written as
early as 1946: “literature is not a subject but _a function_ – a function
inseparable from communal existence.”[5](fm02.html#fm02en5a) In other words,
not only literature matters but it can also become a key to understand our own
world: “After a conventional and devoted initiation to poetry as a romantic
rebellion against mechanical industry and bureaucratic stupidity, Cambridge
was a shock. Richards, Leavis, Eliot and Pound and Joyce in a few weeks opened
the doors of perception on the poetic process, and its role in adjusting the
reader to the contemporary world. _My study of media began and remains rooted
in the work of these men_.”[6](fm02.html#fm02en6a) Literature is therefore the
fundamental component of McLuhan’s original _poetics_. My own understanding of
the term _poetics_ follows Umberto Eco’s definition: poetics is perceived as
the _operative project_ which pervades a specific work and that leads to a
given _form_ , at once “original” and “traditional,” that is linked to other
pre-existing forms.[7](fm02.html#fm02en7a) Moving forward from this
definition, Marshall McLuhan’s poetics is far more complex than normally
recognized, especially as far as _form_ is concerned. Whereas his operative
project is well known – to investigate the impact of new media on human
consciousness and environment, so as to foresee, reveal, and eventually
counterbalance the related side effects – the _form_, which shapes and gives
new functional potential to such a project, is still underestimated. Not only
is McLuhan’s writing discontinuous, but as said, it also is pervaded by
countless literary references and _exempla_ derived from different artistic
expressions. By reading his media analysis and investigations, the reader
perceives that literature and the arts are playing a pivotal role in the
shaping of McLuhan’s writing technique, but how that happens and for what
purpose might not be immediately clear. To appreciate that, we have to
remember that Marshall McLuhan portrayed himself as an _explorer_ and not as
an _explainer_ of media environments. “Mosaic” or “field approach” are the
terms McLuhan himself employed to define these explorations; and “mosaic” was
also his way of rendering them.

### **

Marshall McLuhan’s Mosaic: A Different Approach to Knowledge and Reality**

Marshall McLuhan introduces his idea of “mosaic” in the very first lines of
_Gutenberg Galaxy_ ; he places it before his prologue to warn his readers that
the book they are about to read is somehow “different” and that the difference
is not only in _what_ is discussed but also in _how_ that is done: “ _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ develops a mosaic or field approach to its problems. Such a
mosaic image of numerous data and quotations in evidence offers the only
practical means of revealing causal operations in
history.”[8](fm02.html#fm02en8a) Expanding that definition, we can consider
McLuhan’s mosaic _an operative tool stemming from the humanities_ (McLuhan’s
own understanding of literature as “a function”) _and steering media
actuality_ (by showing the interplay of technology and culture).

What is, in fact, a mosaic? If you think of it, we can associate different
meanings to this term: the mosaic can be an art form (the Roman mosaics, or
the Byzantine mosaics), or a multicultural approach to societal and cultural
phenomena (the Canadian mosaic), or a type of pavement (a mosaic floor). These
are just a few basic examples pertaining to different domains: the artistic or
the aesthetic one, the sociocultural and the political one, the most pragmatic
one of construction and applied design. And yet, if you think of it, they all
have something in common: their operative structure. All these ideas of mosaic
in fact translate into a material or conceptual form based on fragments – or
tiles, or tesserae – that is, discrete units whose assemblage creates a figure
which acquires meaning _through the interplay with its own ground_. By so
doing, a pattern gets created and in turn revealed through our active
observation. _Pattern recognition_ is the way we approach all mosaics: we look
for the overall design that the careful assemblage of the various tesserae
brings to light, something which transcends their mere sum. Pattern
recognition engages us, requires our will to cooperate with the structure; it
turns us into Sherlock Holmes, capable of seeing the narrative of a Roman or a
Byzantine mosaic, as well as of a multicultural one, or even of a mosaic
floor. _We participate in the process of giving meaning to what we
experience_. This is true for all what we define as _a mosaic_ , including
McLuhan’s form of writing: it is a form which encourages an active
participation of all seers, readers, spectators who have to find _the figure
in the carpet_ , which is, in fact, what connects figures and ground.

As _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ clearly shows, McLuhan’s mosaic is therefore a non-
linear form of writing which re-elaborates the alphabetic form so to give the
written page a tactile and multi-sensorial dimension. Just like in modernist
avant-garde experiments, McLuhan designed a page which no longer assimilated “
_utterance to the human body_ ,” a metaphor which returns us to a well-known
entity.[9](fm02.html#fm02en9a) McLuhan’s pages lost the head (no titles but
“chapter glosses”) and the feet (no footnotes, all references are within the
text); they lost their traditional “physicality,” at the same time that the
new “discarnate human beings” of the electric age were losing their sense of
body by extending their psyches into cyberspace. After having defined the
“individual” as a “**MONTAGE OF LOOSELY ASSEMBLED PARTS** ” McLuhan had fun in
disassembling those very parts because “**WHEN YOU ARE ON THE PHONE OR ON THE
AIR YOU HAVE NO BODY**.” The point for us is how to remain “somebody” while
having “no body.” By encouraging our active participation in the process of
discovery, McLuhan’s mosaic also contributes to alert us and to keep us awake;
by engaging with both the mosaic and its complex network of subtexts, we are
trained to be _conscious readers_ and not numbed or homogenized _nobodies_.

### **McLuhan’s Mosaic:_Verbo-vocal-visual_ Potentialities of His _Probes_**

Acting at the forefront of new technological revolutions, McLuhan’s mosaic
developed from a different metaphor, no longer a biological one (our body),
but a technological one: the _probe_ , a flexible object through which we can
carry out explorations not only outside but also inside different bodies. The
probe constitutes the functional tile of McLuhan’s mosaic; it is the smaller
unit which is assembled to convey a pattern, to turn the fixity of the printed
page into an acoustic experience. Pages written around probes incorporate
readers into the text’s landscape; readers of the mosaic are no longer
external observers, they are inside the evolving picture. This means that
readers do not have to approach McLuhan’s printed page as _a thing_ , but
rather as _an event_ in which the act of reading is integral to a
participation in the process of discovery.

From the late sixties, the hippie youth movement got and celebrated McLuhan’s
form of communication better than other audiences, the idea of “happening”
being at the core of their life philosophy. Needless to say, the appreciation
coming from the countercultures of the young rebels did not contribute to the
appreciation of McLuhan’s scholarly work, nor did Yoko Ono and John Lennon’s
visits to McLuhan’s Coach House in Toronto: it was the confirmation that
McLuhan was but a _media guru_ , a _techno fan_ who made money out of the
_love &peace_ world. Certainly, he did not foster his cause as a professor of
English by proclaiming that “**COMPUTERS ARE THE LSD OF THE CORPORATE WORLD**
” or that “**THE NEW TOURISTS ARE THE INNER TRIPPERS** ,” thinking of the side
effects of then new media such as TV, but only because his readers _did not
put him on_ as well. If you free these so-called slogans from the tyranny of
_literate_ words, you will appreciate them as interactive probes connecting us
to a broader network of concepts. McLuhan’s probes are in fact USB flash
drives interfacing us and the broken knowledge in his texts: they are verbo-
vocal-visual devices which triggers sensorial synaesthesia in the way we
perceive and inhabit our inner and outer landscapes.

The density of the probe, its aphoristic and paratactic structure, as well as
its connection to the paradoxical aim to counterbalance its brevity by
encouraging a deeper and more engaging investigation. It is not by chance that
McLuhan also called these probes _glosses_ – as in _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ –
therefore employing a term used in biblical exegesis to explain passages in
the text; a term which was also used to indicate marginal notes in manuscripts
and printed versions of texts both in the classic and the vulgar tradition. A
_probe_ or _gloss_ is a dynamic rhetorical device envisaged as a textual
addition that creates a series of related patterns of knowledge inside and
outside the text itself. If readers read _through_ the probe – that is, if
they see it as a window opening on a broader (textual and contextual)
landscape – they read _in depth_ , investigating and discussing possible
meanings, links, and further implications. If they skip from a probe to the
next one quickly, they can just have fun and use the mosaic as a form of
amusing diversion which, nevertheless, can induce unexpected associations and,
in time, even understanding and knowledge. After all, humour was a favourite
tenet of McLuhan’s form of communication.

Hence, to my mind, the _probe_ or _gloss_ constitutes the fundamental
component of McLuhan’s mosaic. The probe is used to convey a broken knowledge
as in the aphoristic tradition; even if it often sounds like a formula, it
forces you to become an active player. The probe is in effect McLuhan’s
rhetorical device aimed at triggering intertextuality and operating as a link
to other textual and contextual situations. As you will discover when reading
_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , each probe introduces a set of apparently unrelated
questions, which are often conveyed in a paradoxical – and therefore
provocative – way and which readers are asked to explore. In time, McLuhan
developed different types of probes, moving from traditional aphorisms to
paratactic constructions involving also images but the function of the probe
or gloss remains the same: to provoke and engage the readers and encourage a
different approach to situations by turning them into “active players”
interfacing a substantial discontinuity.

Even though the questions placed at the beginning of each of the forty-nine
chapters of McLuhan’s first published book, _The Mechanical Bride_
(1951),[10](fm02.html#fm02en10a) can be approached as first versions of
“probes” or “glosses,” it is in _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ that the probe becomes
a clearly conceived structural element of McLuhan’s prose. Here is an example
of one of McLuhan’s probes/glosses – or even “one-image poems” – from _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_. You do not have to read it. You have _to experience it_ ,
that is, to read _through it_ :

### **Civilization gives

the barbarian or tribal man an eye for an ear and is now at odds with the
electric world**

If you read through it, you find yourself digging out an idea that explores
the historical interface of orality and literacy through time. This probe
immediately renders the cyclic vision of human history, as expressed by
McLuhan himself in his grand narrative on media. Here, he retrieves the
metaphorical structure of language and plays with it. The terms _barbarian or
tribal man_ , _civilization_ , _electric world_ immediately evoke three
different social constructs; they imply three different relationships between
the individual and the environment, also denoting a different sensorial order.
Here in one fell swoop is: the world _before_ the invention of the phonetic
alphabet; the world _after_ the phonetic alphabet and printing press; the
world _after_ the commercialization of electricity. The passage from _ear_ to
_eye_ indicates the passage from the ancient acoustic mode of perception –
inclusive and simultaneous – typical of tribal society to a sequential and
linear one pertaining to the literate Western society, now obsolete or no
longer adequate to (_at odds with_) the electric environment (which, through
its retribalization, is rediscovering acoustic and tribal dynamics). This
probe (as all the others) can therefore be figured out in depth, and used as a
way to access a more complex ground. In a similar way, all other probes
encapsulate knowledge that readers are asked to retrieve.

Like most modernist writings, McLuhan’s writing is an _open writing_ , a sort
of _writing in progress_ which acquires new and different meanings depending
on the act of reading and therefore depending on the readers, who are
therefore transformed into co-producers of meaning. McLuhan defined this
process of continuous interplay and exegesis as a “**do-it-yourself
participation on the part of the reader**.” He freed word from the tyranny of
the School of Paris and took it back to the School of Athens; he retrieved the
‘evocative power’ of words, and their potentialities to combine through a
knowledge broken so to open all doors of perception. As a grammarian of the
electric age, McLuhan insisted that “**LANGUAGE DOES FOR INTELLIGENCE WHAT THE
WHEEL DOES FOR THE FEET AND THE BODY**.” Language is in fact a key term when
approaching McLuhan. And literature, which he studied, can be approached as
the gathering of texts that form the matrix of languages.

### **The Mosaic: Hyper _text_ or Hyper _language_?**

McLuhan’s probes or glosses are built upon an artist-like use of imagination,
intuition and language; however, starting with _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ he
applied them with a probing (and playful) attitude to all cognitive fields, to
all forms of knowledge, to all media (generally taken as both products and
extensions of man and of his faculties). As Derrick de Kerckhove has pointed
out, McLuhan explored “an area of knowledge usually reserved to human sciences
through artistic methods and through the articulation of
language.”[11](fm02.html#fm02en11a) It is exactly _the articulation of
language_ which is important in McLuhan’s mosaic. In this context, language is
to be understood as an _arché_ unifying _forma et substancia_ (literally
_form_ and _substance_), thus becoming the cognitive agent which shaped his
original aphoristic style, at once combining an ancient knowledge with avant-
garde formal experiments. McLuhan was a humanist acting inside the electric
age, pursuing an eclectic approach to knowledge and actuality, collecting
materials from various fields and cultural languages; his holistic and
inclusive approach to mobile situations (often dismissed as trivial
generality) aimed to reveal new social patterns, that is, to point to the
various larger figures in the carpet. Consistently, his form of communication,
as well as his “field approach to situations,” was _humanistic_ , at once
_eclectic_ and _electric_ : he borrowed from literary and artistic traditions
and elaborated his findings into an original discourse whose fuzzy syntax
puzzled those who could not chew on his aphorisms.

When McLuhan was “rediscovered” after a decade of oblivion following his
death, he was immediately turned into the patron saint of the world of
information and communication technology. In a short span of time, his
oracular pronouncements were read instead as prophetical messages and he was
resurrected as the great guru of the media-geeks tribe. It is true that
McLuhan did anticipate future developments of information and communication
technology with uncanny precision. He did not envision the production of the
BlackBerry, iPod, or iPhone, but he imagined their technological effects and
anticipated the environmental side effects of the digital and interactive
technologies which we now manage daily. But, alas, if you take time to read
his books, or to watch his video interviews you will immediately realize that
McLuhan himself was the first to remind his audiences that he had carefully
predicted only what had already happened! Yes, it is a witty and paradoxical
statement, but with the paradox comes the serious revelation derived from the
humanistic philosophical traditions: the effect always precedes the formal
cause, so much so that the future can only be an invention of the past. This
paradox invites us to reconsider a technological metaphor that is often
applied to McLuhan’s own form of communication; as a matter of fact, the
mosaic is too readily defined as a hypertext _ante-litteram_. By doing this we
translate what is perhaps a more complex form into what we immediately
understand and associate today with interactivity and multimedia
communications. But isn’t such a comparison a cliché that limits a real
understanding of the way in which the mosaic interfaces with readers,
knowledge, and actuality? Following a brilliant essay by Michel A.
Moos,[12](fm02.html#fm02en12a) I am more inclined to approach McLuhan’s mosaic
as a hyper _language_ discussing new technologies _through the humanities_.

Generally speaking, all definitions seem to converge on the idea that, in
practice, hypertext is an updated version of Bush’s _memex_ – a neologism
combining the ideas of memory and index – a device conceptualized as early as
1945.[13](fm02.html#fm02en13a) However, if it had been presented to King
Thamus as a gift to improve our memory or thought, quite certainly the _memex_
would have prompted the same judgment that he pronounced when Theuth
introduced the invention of writing to him. This episode, originally recalled
by Plato in his _Phaedrus_ , is by now a classic in communication studies and
it is often quoted to epitomize the way people tend to look at the pointing
finger and not at the moon beyond it. As you might remember, Theuth, a famous
god and inventor of Naucratis in Egypt, showed several of his inventions to
the god Thamus, “the king of the whole country of Egypt”; while so doing, he
enumerated the advantages that each of them would bring to their people. When
he came to literacy, “the letters,” Theuth praised that invention as capable
to enhance people’s memory and therefore wit. Thamus surprised him by replying
that, instead, writing was nothing but a means to trigger forgetfulness to the
detriment of real wisdom and knowledge. Since “the parent or inventor of an
art is not always the best judge of the utility or inutility of his own
inventions to the users of them,”[14](fm02.html#fm02en14a) Thamus showed
Theuth the full moon beyond his finger. From that moment, Thamus warned
Theuth, people would instead become more and more ignorant, relying on writing
to bring things to their remembrance through external signs. People would lose
the capability to look through things, to participate in the process of
learning; they would have “the show of wisdom without the reality.” If my
parallel stands, then the _memex_ is to memory as writing is to orality. The
point now is to decide if McLuhan’s probes and mosaic relate more to writing
and memex or to memory and orality. My idea is that, being verbo-vocal-visual
“tools,” the probes and the mosaic _substance_ is closer to the latter pair,
even though their _function_ might recall the one offered by “links” in
hypertexts.

In his essay, Moos considers McLuhan’s probes or glosses as adapter cables
which activate interfacing, juxtaposing different media on what stays as a
“text-based operating system.”[15](fm02.html#fm02en15a) The form “book” is
renewed through the contact with “the diverse and discontinuous life forms,”
at the same time revealing a new exploratory technique: “[McLuhan] shows you
how you can take the low-tech interface of the page and reverse engineer it so
it can handle other inputs, so that you can, in effect, plug other media into
it.”[16](fm02.html#fm02en16a) McLuhan’s mosaic is an inclusive and
simultaneous form of writing which “optimizes language on the page with better
compression techniques, enlarged memory storage, and enhances program
logic”;[17](fm02.html#fm02en17a) it overcomes linearity and opens the phonetic
form to new potentialities.

The form of McLuhan’s mosaic is born out of the meeting of orality and
literacy, and the resulting extraordinary intensity snaps us out of the
Narcissus-narcosis imposed on our senses by the mechanicity of literacy. This
form certainly anticipates later forms of communication, such as hypertext;
also, it certainly shares similar tenets to hypertext itself in structure
(i.e., the analogical combination of probes and textual fragments) and in
modes of fruitions (i.e., the possibility to freely move backward and forward
inside the text). But as a _form_ it is meaningfully different because it is
rooted in the ancient liberal art of _grammar_. This is something that today
hypertext does not necessarily imply. What this grounding implies is an
approach to knowledge based on “the art of exposition and interpretation of
phenomena”[18](fm02.html#fm02en18a) rather than a compartmentalized take on
concepts and ideas which are then assembled in hypertextual modes.

McLuhan’s mosaic is primarily a tool enhancing our capability to learn and
apprehend through the interplay of ancient wisdom and cognitive stimulation;
it is not simply a way to convey simultaneity and dress knowledge in a format
employing different media models in order to offer a more _lively_ , _real_ ,
and _immediate_ experience. It is not, so to speak, the embodiment of the
media fan but of the media grammarian. The mosaic relies on the witty power of
puns and words to perceive analogies between apparently unrelated things. It
opens windows to unpack all the _compressed_ learning embedded in language:
quoting Bacon and his nineteenth-century commentators, Moos rightly recalls
the concept of _portability of thought_ based on “an internal mobility of
language through which thought itself advances.”[19](fm02.html#fm02en19a) Such
a concept is also assessed in relation to McLuhan’s own study of H.A. Innis’s
language, where McLuhan defines each of Innis’s sentences as a compressed
monograph: “He includes a small library on each page, and often incorporates a
small library of references on the same page in
addition.”[20](fm02.html#fm02en20a) Consequently, reading becomes an active
process not simply because it enables us to understand what is written in the
book and to participate in the creation of meaning, but mostly because it
encourages us to continue exploring, and if we fully engage in that form it
will further foster knowledge. As Moos insightfully suggests, McLuhan’s
writing (as well as Innis’s) does not anticipate hypertext as a database that
we can access, but as “a mode of thinking that reaches back into your own
‘headset’ and accesses you.” The mosaic taps “into the reader, to access and
activate his inner storehouse”: “The effect is to enable those very functions
computer hypertext regards as a constitutive yet still strives to define,
namely, integration of the reader into the writing process and real-time
access to the archive ... Thus Innis ‘expects the reader to make discovery
after discovery that he himself had missed.’”[21](fm02.html#fm02en21a)

The act of reading the mosaic then is envisaged as an experience which
enhances the process of construction of knowledge, as well as a process of
_actualization_ of a knowledge elaborated through time and space by language.
It is that very process of actualization which awakens readers from the
Narcissus-narcosis. The mosaic, as the form which embeds and allows such an
experience, is a _cold_ medium or a truly _tactile_
one[22](fm02.html#fm02en22a) because it forces the reader to compensate for
what is not obvious in the text but which is nevertheless present and
compressed in a probe or in a pun. The _portability of thought_ so translated
is what makes the mosaic a hyper _language_ more than a hyper _text_. After
all, language is an oral/acoustic concept and text is a linear one, with all
that implies in terms of sensorial awareness and active participation.

In _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , McLuhan recapitulates the glosses at the very end
of the book in a sequence which can be perceived as an _imagistic_ table of
contents for the whole book. As Ezra Pound taught us, an image “is that which
presents an intellectual and an emotional complex in an instant of
time.”[23](fm02.html#fm02en23a) It creates synaesthesia, simultaneity,
multiple perspectives, intellectual and emotional links. Readers could, in
fact, work just on the probes listed at the end as if they were “imagistic
images,” juxtaposing them in order to trigger new speculations,
understandings, and knowledge. By so doing, readers are promoted to the role
of co-creators. The aphoristic probes contained in the end index evoke all
that which is discussed in the book. The insightful reader can act as a
storyteller and extend McLuhan’s production of meaning and knowledge. In this
sense, the probes can be perceived not only as idea boxes, but also as imagist
one-liners and contextual puns, in the sense that Pound meant his cantos to be
read. What is first hidden in the clever musicality opens itself, upon
reflection, to a concrete representation of an idea. Upon reflection, we find
out that the probes are not being juxtaposed according to a linear
subordination, but instead aimed at triggering associations.

### Post-literate _Paideia_

It is through language that McLuhan taught us how to understand the way new
media reconfigure our world in the _form_ of a global village. Through
language, he probed how cultural, societal, and communicative dynamics shift
inside a highly technological environment. Through language, he tried to
awaken us and alert us to the difficulties of grasping the long-term effects
of all technological innovations on our senses and on our realities. How was
McLuhan able to “see” and to “understand” ahead of others (since the 1950s)
situations which are all too obvious to us today? What turned him into a
sagacious _visionary_ or _media prophet_? My answers are precise. It was his
humanistic background, his passion for literature, and his capability of
developing a way of simultaneously _looking at_ and _through_ things based on
his lifelong training in the humanities.

By definition, a “humanist” is: (1) a believer in the principles of humanism;
(2) one who is concerned with the interest and welfare of humans; (3) a
classical scholar; (4) a student of the liberal arts; (5) a Renaissance
scholar devoted to Humanism. McLuhan was all these definitions at once: he
wrote his PhD dissertation on English Renaissance, offering a deep analysis of
the liberal arts of the trivium (grammar, rhetoric,
dialectic);[24](fm02.html#fm02en24a) as an intellectual, he believed in the
liberal and lay principles of Humanism and was deeply concerned with the
interests and welfare of humans in his own time. Being a humanist, McLuhan’s
ideas of _welfare_ and _interest_ , though, did not concern merely the
material side of the human existence, but also the intellectual and the
emotional; his own interest in media derived from the need to fully understand
the impact that the evolving technological, cultural, and sociological
processes were having on us humans. Freedom, independence, and free will
result from knowledge and understanding of what is really going on around us,
as he clearly assumes in the introduction to his first published book, _The
Mechanical Bride. The Gutenberg Galaxy_ provides a method to translate that
lesson into an operative strategy of investigation.

With _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ McLuhan shared his own _reading process_ of the
world, which is, in fact, a carefully conceived epistemological mode of
investigation. As a humanist, he opted for Francis Bacon’s _broken knowledge_
and _aphorisms_ – which he actualized through his thorough investigation of
the great modernist masters – so to encourage his readers to enquire further
by themselves.[25](fm02.html#fm02en25a) The process of reading and
understanding (a book, the world) is what is at stake in _The Gutenberg
Galaxy_. While _reading_ his writing, you also _experience_ the world or the
situation he is processing analogically: his mosaic is a form which defines
McLuhan as a “post-secondary orality” humanist or media theorist, a definition
which is to be explored in the light of his scholarly background, as well as
of his lifelong curiosity for all human productions.

He turned upside down what had been effectively established by centuries of
serious schooling, suggesting new modes of explorations based on the shocking
association of apparently disparate ideas and topics. He experimented with
interdisciplinarity before interdisciplinary studies were the fashion. And,
even worse, he appeared to enjoy it! Most critics accused him of being too
enthusiastic about all that was new; quite ironically, he was in fact acting
on the basis of very ancient and traditional paradigms. In the never-ending
battle of books, McLuhan stood for the ancients, not for the moderns, because
his idea of knowledge was rooted in the arts of the trivium and was strongly
shaped by a grammarian’s approach. His media theories derive, in effect, from
that knowledge of the trivium and are developed through its application. “By
surpassing writing we have regained our WHOLENESS, not on a national or
cultural but cosmic plane,”[26](fm02.html#fm02en26a) he wrote. Being a
grammarian, McLuhan explored such wholeness in his vocation, looking for
_connections through differences_ , acting on a cosmic plane himself.

McLuhan elaborated a new way of looking at our habitat. He combined scholarly
background, knowledge of contemporary literature and art, as well as pop
culture to explore what was going on around him and to alert his readers to
the ongoing cultural processes. With _The Gutenberg Galaxy_, he showed us that
only an _integrated approach_ brings together different domains which
contribute to our understanding of the _wholeness_ of the then electric, and
now Internet and digital, age. Consistently, he insisted that in the
information age, the specialist is an anachronism, someone that, according to
him, “never makes small mistakes while moving toward the grand
fallacy.”[27](fm02.html#fm02en27a) He reconsidered the idea of education and
refused the compartmentalized academic methods of investigation, since they no
longer mirrored the new reality. To observe the electric simultaneity through
the rear-view mirror of linearity would imply to rely upon a distorted version
of reality. For McLuhan, the time had come to change spectacles and adopt new
lenses. What is fascinating to discover is that McLuhan’s _new spectacles_
were in fact the _ancient trivium_.

In his books, McLuhan applies the modernist lesson and uses avant-garde
experimental works to explore and draw parallels between the new media-induced
landscape and ancient forms of societies and educational patterns. _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ , for example, retrieves some of the tenets explored in his
doctoral dissertation, as well as Bacon’s lesson, and establishes the mosaic
as a form at once retrieving and triggering knowledge. At the same time, in
his public lectures, he continuously discussed the role of education in a mass
society. In particular, he encouraged a “totally new
approach”[28](fm02.html#fm02en28a) leading to a “global education program that
will enable us to seize the reins of our destiny.”[29](fm02.html#fm02en29a)
Such a program would serve not to homogenize people’s thought (“to win
consent,” in Bacon’s words), but, on the contrary, to induce a critical
attitude to media in general. McLuhan considered higher education as the
necessary tool to counterbalance cultural homologation; by higher education he
meant a _classic_ education. The ancient _paideia_ , a Greek term meaning “to
educate,” is associated with the idea of a rounded cultural education pursued
in the light of a public life engaged in public good and interest. Paideia is
therefore the tool that McLuhan postulated as the only one capable to
counterbalance the subliminal effects of new media on the human sensorium. For
McLuhan, literature and the arts were the instruments through which the
ancient paideia could be retrieved. His laws of media are based on such
pedagogical principles and form a post-literate tool that enhances paideia;
they are a carefully conceived system of observation based on the combined
action of the trivium, with a special emphasis on the “evocative power” of
words.[30](fm02.html#fm02en30a)

McLuhan’s mosaic is fully inscribed inside such an educational philosophy; it
challenges the idea that knowledge proceeds through a progressive line and
refutes the idea that new knowledge results from the mere accumulation of data
and concepts. As a discontinuous form, the mosaic forces readers to shift from
a visual (linear) to an acoustic (all-at-once) perspective; by so doing, the
mosaic teaches us to acquire a simultaneous vision of various phenomena,
acting simultaneously, in the here and now, and constantly affecting the
phenomena.

Setting McLuhan’s mosaic and his educational philosophy in his own time, we
can recognize that he set off on a very difficult mission. His most celebrated
books (_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ [1962]; _Understanding Media_ [1964]) came out
just a few years before the countercultures of the sixties exploded worldwide.
Knowledge was instrumental to the preservation of traditional institutions;
the classroom was a place where you went to listen to your teachers and to
learn notions by the book and not to question them. In the sixties, when
McLuhan established his famous Monday night seminars at the Coach House, at
the University of Toronto, his classroom looked like an agora, a piazza,
rather than a traditional classroom. His lessons were conceived as _probes_
challenging students and listeners to think about his media observations; as a
professor, he wanted to _turn them on_. Those who attended his seminars still
remember them as both engaging and entertaining; also, they recall how, a few
years later when McLuhan had become renowned worldwide, they attracted VIPs
and many celebrities to the Coach House. At the Coach House, McLuhan and his
well-known guests provocatively urged the students to join them in their
explorations. He invited them to approach literature and the arts as tools
facilitating the sensorial and cognitive shift from the ivory tower to the
control tower. What McLuhan suggested in those seminars is that _creativity is
the perfect antidote to all fear of change_. He often reminded them of Edgar
Allan Poe’s sailor, of his adventure in the maelstrom, and of the way he used
rational detachment and amusement to overcome terror.[31](fm02.html#fm02en31a)

As early as 1959, in a lecture offered to the American Association for Higher
Education, McLuhan anticipated that “the future of the book is
inclusive.”[32](fm02.html#fm02en32a) On that occasion, he set the book against
the new electric ground formed by radio and television and suggested that in
the new age, children and students would learn more and more through
apprenticeship and less and less through study. He was right. Today we know
that the new cultural and technological context preserves literacy and the
book but encourages them both to respond to their new electric ground; they
are two literate figures which must adjust to a clear sensorial and
environmental change.

The old medium stays around but it is reshaped according to the new
potentialities embedded by the new media. Learning from previous avant-garde
movements such as symbolism, futurism, or vorticism, McLuhan understood that
_the written page had to become the interface through which the new electric
simultaneity would reveal itself_ at a time when hypertexts were but a
speculative possibility among a limited group of researchers. The paradox
underpinning the elaboration of the mosaic style of writing is how to open the
old medium – writing – to new media in order to preserve the thought processes
of the old medium itself. But it is, in turn, part of another paradox which is
implicit in the very form of the electric media. The new _acoustic_ perception
must, in fact, be expressed through a form which is inevitably (and here is
the paradox) _visually_ rendered and shaped. The new electric age comes after
the literate age, and could even be interpreted as its ultimate product; by
necessity, according to McLuhan, it must take the literate age as its content.
Individuals cannot cancel centuries of literacy – even if they think they can
– because the orality induced by the new electric media is, in fact, itself a
_literate_ secondary orality. Instead of asking the old question, can Dick and
Jane read? we now ask: are they media _literate_?

As Ong reminded us, secondary orality is a sort of “impure” and “hybrid”
orality since in it both writing and printing stay as fundamental components
of the new technological language.[33](fm02.html#fm02en33a) It is, in fact, a
_parole_ , a word or spoken language determined by acoustic and tactile means.
Secondary orality is so called because by its very nature or “physiology” it
is both spoken-as-written and/or written-as-spoken and is the related
interplay of speech and text, that is, the perceptive dynamics which take
place between media and its users on the computer screen; or when text
messaging; or when activating applications through image and touch on iPhones.
The acoustic aspect, as implied by McLuhan, means the remodelling of the
environment by turning it from a visual bias to an oral bias while, at the
same time, using older media as fundamental components of the ongoing
communicative process: old media integrate into new media and are re-
elaborated into new formal combinations and hybrids. “**NEW MEDIA DO NOT
REPLACE EACH OTHER, THEY COMPLICATE EACH OTHER.** ” A new medium often
enhances the subtler proprieties of old ones which one has so far neglected
because of a standardized use. McLuhan called this paradox “the rear-view
mirror effect.”

Now imagine the kind of change digital access will bring to analogue content,
causing a convergence that will mediate the total mediascape into the content
of thought. That no longer is the world of secondary orality, as per Ong. New
digital media retrieve both the alphabet and the printed word and include them
in the newly convergent **_post-secondary orality_** : this is our new
evolving ground. Through digital media, we are shifting from secondary orality
to post-secondary orality. What is now done in digital hypertexts McLuhan had
already started doing on the printed page. His discontinuous mosaic form of
writing was what showed me, in 1996 when I first read _Gutenberg Galaxy_ , the
new potentialities inherent to the old linear medium of print. Released and
freed from a too-rigid structure imposed by the mechanics of print culture,
words can retrieve ancient heuristic properties linked to ancient societal
constructs and systems of knowledge. Today, we are but on the brink of these
new heuristic potentialities emphasized and retrieved by new forms of media
which seem to enhance participation in process more than privacy and
detachment (albeit in vicarious ways).

McLuhan was not around when the World Wide Web exploded onto the world, but he
read Norbert Weiner and understood that the book as an object would be
preserved in the electrified command and control of the computer age; in fact,
he cross-read and applied various semantics. He grasped what the new form
would do to cybernetics and communication studies and reconfigured its effect
and how it will launch the new electric tribal circle. Adopting and adapting
strategies already examined by modernist explorers, he turned his printed
pages into interfaces detecting and revealing the new electric simultaneity.
The mosaic style of writing encourages deep participation; both words and
gaps, both knowledge and ignorance, play a role in the process. Not only are
we asked to investigate bold associations, but we must also let the interval
through which they juxtapose resound and resonate through what we know and
don’t know. Its broken knowledge combines knowingness and unknowingness with
modernist heuristics; montage and collage are not just techniques used to
disrupt linearity, they become rhetorical strategies employed to retrieve _the
complexity of generating new knowledge_. If we do not play according to the
rhetorician’s intention, we risk turning the complex architecture into a
trivial version of the reader’s digest. A similar risk is always present when
exploring the World Wide Web: we jump from a _fragment_ to the next one, but
if we do not make the interval _resonate_ , we flatten our understanding and
turn _knowledge_ into _information_; we also tend to oversimplify complex
issues, and neglect history or the nature of our stratified memories (we move
from the School of Athens to the School of Paris, so to speak). In the late
fifties, McLuhan suggested that in order to counterbalance the side effects of
new cultural forces and educational agencies – already acting outside the
classroom and turning students into “consumers,” “co-authors,” and “co-
producers” of both information and knowledge – teachers and scholars should no
longer be “the source of data but of _insight_.” Consistently, his probes do
not translate data, but _the dynamics underpinning the probing process_ of
which the mosaic is the interactive playground: while engaging with the
mosaic, we learn _by apprenticeship_ , _by doing_.

The anthropologist Edmund (Ted) Carpenter, Marshall McLuhan’s lifelong friend
and colleague, wrote that “knowledge of media alone is not sufficient
protection from them.” A fact, he explained, that also applied to the man who
taught us how to understand media: “The moment Marshall McLuhan shifted from
private media analyst to public media participant, he was converted into an
image media manipulated & exploited.”[34](fm02.html#fm02en34a) One hundred
years after his birth, we have now the occasion to return McLuhan from figure
(his media image) to ground (the complex bringing together of his media
investigations as well as his scholarly formation) by probing his mosaic and,
through that, assessing the literary roots of all his discourses on media.
Well, it’s THAT what makes McLuhan’s “little point” so original and _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ not just a book on media but a book on our own way to
perceive change and environments as “human beings.” Enjoy your reading of _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ , playfully accept McLuhan’s challenge; learn by doing. Read
and play with his narrative because “**AT PLAY MAN USES ALL HIS FACULTIES; AT
WORK HE SPECIALISES**.”

## **The Invisible and the Visible: Intertwining Figure and Ground in _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_**

DOMINIQUE SCHEFFEL-DUNAND

Almost sixty years ago, Herbert Marshall McLuhan published _The Gutenberg
Galaxy: The Making of Typographic Man_. Marsh Jeanneret, reflecting on
scholarly publishing at the University of Toronto Press as its director,
clearly states that _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ (1962) was a publishing landmark.
“UofT Press sold about 55,000 copies in hardback and in the Canadian
University Paperbooks edition, plus 135,000 copies in a mass-market paperback
format, for which they leased rights to the New American Library” (Jeanneret
1989, 155). In the spring of 1963 Marshall McLuhan was presented with the
Governor General’s Award for this critical and expository prose. McLuhan
continued to transcend scholarly publishing in much of what he wrote, in most
of what he said, and always in the way he responded to popular acceptation.
His books introduced into the language our present usage of the terms “age of
information” and “global village,” which have since become commonplaces. But
even as McLuhan passed across the zenith of his fame, and is now viewed as the
prophet of the Internet age, without question “he was, in 1962, one of the
most influential thinkers of his day” (Jeanneret 1989, 156). By reading _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ as an _essai_ (essay) we are proposing to read the mind-
opening analogies, inserted between historical displays of ideas, with the
eyes of a flâneur and detached observer, anchored in the culture of McLuhan’s
time and much influenced by the Renaissance. And to the twenty-first-century
reader gazing at the ongoing displacement of the monochromatic type on a page
by interactive, multidimensional graphics and sound bites in digital scholarly
publishing, we say that designing a post-Gutenbergian model of knowledge and
scholarly communication does not entail obliterating the past.

More than fifty years after the publication of _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , the
most inspiring lesson for a writer is thus McLuhan’s strategic and tactile
understanding of print, as a medium of inscription, to delineate the
boundaries of thought and the interstices between ideas. In a prefatory note
to _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , McLuhan eschews the linear form of a consecutive
argument for his book, and presents it as a “mosaic” or field approach to the
grasping of the technologies emerging then. Such a mosaic image of critical
prose and quoted elements offered McLuhan means of revealing causal operations
in history. To visually display his unorthodox approach, the main body of the
book is arranged in the form of 261 more or less self-contained sections, each
headed with a punning, epigrammatic, or summarizing statement in large, bold,
italic type. Theoretically and as suggested by the author, the sections might
be read in any order. The truth is that the mosaic is more than window
dressing, and in its form _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ follows the classic pattern
of the essay as a vehicle for the process, rather than the end results, of
thought. From the Low Latin _essagium_ (cf. the Italian _saggio_ and the
Spanish _ensayo_), _essai_ or _coup d’essai_ evolved in its usage to mean
“testing,” “trying out,” or “probing.” McLuhan, like Montaigne, sees in the
essay structure the testing of the judgment, the mind, the senses, and to an
extent, the whole being. The essay allows the replacement of logical thought
by free associations and artistically visually controlled juxtapositions of
ideas. _Galaxy_ contains a wealth of fascinating and novel material about the
culture of the past 2500 years, and the galaxy McLuhan describes does exist.
_Galaxy_ is an “undisciplined” contribution to the study of the effect of
print on Western culture, and when included in the writingscapes of academe,
it is the only work of its kind for its form at the time of its publishing. To
reflect on the form of the book is thus a first step at understanding why _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ is still today such a publishing landmark for the time, and
will ever remain a publishing landmark for scholars and universities as
publishers.

In the postscript, “The Galaxy Reconfigured or the Plight of Mass Man in an
Individualist Society,” McLuhan suggests that we are beginning to understand
the Gutenberg era only because “we have moved into another phase from which we
can contemplate the contours of the preceding situation with ease and clarity
... As we experience the new electronic and organic age with ever stronger
indications of its main outlines, the preceding mechanical age becomes more
intelligible” (_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , 275).

Technological determinism is not McLuhan’s invention, for it underpins
respectable scholarly works as Lewis Mumford’s _Technics and Civilization_
(1934), Abbott Payson Usher’s _A History of Mechanical Inventions_ (1929,
1954). The theme of the revolutionary impact of changes in communications
informs, among other works, H.J. Chaytor’s _From Script to Print_ (1945), Eric
Havelock’s _Preface to Plato_ (1963), Harold A. Innis’s _The Bias of
Communication_ (1951), and André Malraux’s _Les voix du silence_ (1951).
Insightful studies of the historical transformation of human perception, to
which McLuhan is indebted, include Dorothy Lee’s _Freedom and Culture_ (1958),
E.S. Carpenter’s _Eskimo_ (1959), Edward T. Hall’s _The Silent Language_
(1959). In these works, relatively novel when _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ was
published in 1962, the authors discern the hidden impact of technology and the
cultural variations in perceptual experience. In _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ ,
McLuhan contributes to these twentieth-century views with his attempt to
interpret many aspects of experience as shaped by technologies of
communication. He weaves the diverse observations of others (extensively
quoted and credited) into a series of probes discerning significances where
others see information.

The form of the essay stems from the collections of quotations and aphorisms
which were a very popular genre that helped to spread humanistic material and
learning in the sixteenth century and onward. Montaigne’s earliest essays are
very short and thick with quotations from classical and other writers. The
essayist’s goal is to reflect on his or her own art of writing while testing
his or her ideas. Montaigne’s successors such as Nashe, Mallarmé, and Pound
understood the inexhaustible potentiality of testing oneself against an
infinite variety of subjects with the essay, as a structure, allowing them to
say almost everything about any subject. Their use of vivid, bold images,
epigrammatic wordplay, and a disdain for logical connectives make their texts
“familiar” and “poetic.” Nashe’s critical prose, scrutinized by McLuhan as he
was writing his thesis on this most original Elizabethan writer, convinced
McLuhan that the essayist “attempts” an argument, and his text is coextensive
with a humanistic commitment to rhetoric as performance. The language Nashe
explores in his commercial writing is reflected in McLuhan use of punchy lines
such as “Civilization gives the barbarian or tribal man an eye for an ear and
is now at odds with the electronic world”(26) and “The Homeric hero becomes a
split-man as he assumes an individual ego” (51) for the headings of _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_.

While Mallarmé’s and Pound’s essays are based on the premise of the supremacy
of poetry, they do not condescend on the visual and auditory forms on a page.
Their writings invite a creative reading, an intellectual debate, with the
words and letters. Their fragmentary formulations are witty and suggestive
rather than explicit and didactic, and the initial visual and audio stimuli
become springboards for more wide-ranging meditation on art. No modernist poet
relied so heavily upon the genre of the essay as Pound. McLuhan as well, in
_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , clearly demonstrates his knowledge of the philosophy
of composition when he makes extensive use of juxtapositions, called by Pound
the “ideographic method.” McLuhan, like Montaigne, Mallarmé, and Pound,
understands and uses visual and acoustic language as a metaphor. This
technique allows him to balance visual and acoustic modes of expression from
other modes of communication. Modelling comprehension of the effects of
technologies on man and culture as a kind of ascetic information processing
allows McLuhan to reconceive the material subjects of his inquiry, giving it a
universal appeal and approach that could be revivified today when trying to
make sense of the effects of digitality on the e-book or on scholarly
dissemination of knowledge.

The variety of graphic marks that Marshall McLuhan and Harold Kurschenska
designed for _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , and later McLuhan and Quentin Fiore in
_The Medium is the Massage_ and _War and Peace in the Global Village_ , are
playful encrypted messages that required and still require decipherment. All
of these books are landmarks in the integration of texts, images, and layout
in the values of the publishing industry where a divide persisted between
words and pictures, and between academia and mass media, in the 1960s. For
Brian Donnelly (_Touch, Community and Aesthetics: Where Harold Kurschenska’s
Designs Take Us_ , 2004), what arose in the late 1950s, and particularly in
the work of Harold Kurschenska, was the understanding that design extended
beyond the cover and title page; it ran right through into the handcraft, the
specification and implementation of the many details of each page, letter by
letter and line by line. In attending to the material details of production,
values other than radical innovation necessarily prevailed. What distinguishes
_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ from _The Medium is the Massage_ (published only five
years after _Galaxy_) is that the rule of the book, with its many conventions
governing the order of the preliminary pages, the interplay of margins and
body text, and the subtle and limited freedom necessary for legibility above
all else, is still present (Donnelly 2004). Set against the visual
explorations of mid-century modernism in the United States (such as Warhol’s),
Kurschenska’s designs are unfortunately perceived today as hardly innovative.
But, the strength of Kurschenska’s work lies in three things: “its
sophisticated understanding and use of the _touch_ and feel of printed
material; its appeal to _community_ through clarity and efficiency; and an
aesthetic that could perhaps best be described as preferring the _minimal_
necessary innovation” (Donnelly 2004, 10).

In _Galaxy_ McLuhan treats words, sounds, space, lines, punctuation, page
layout as the ground demanding sustained decoding of its meanings at various
levels. While Fiore gave McLuhan’s ideas their most popular form, McLuhan was
already an accessible writer with a multimedia brain, and _The Gutenberg
Galaxy_ has chapter glosses that already read like advertising headlines.
Using the figure/ground technique to unmask the invisible indicates that
McLuhan is faithful to the Renaissance and Enlightenment. Somewhat reducing
communication to inscriptions, gestures, and silences allows McLuhan to trick
the powers of perception for productive engagement with a no longer discrete
and hierarchical thought processing. Like a Joycean linguistic machine staging
diverse multisensory readings, he highlights with the form of his text the
aesthetic, historical, and humanistic dimensions of perception, whether he
depicts “tribal man” or “alphabetic man.”

In _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ McLuhan links print, radio, and television to
artistic and scientific explorations, illustrating to the reader that the
history of art coincides with the history of perception. Vision and its
effects are always inseparable from the possibilities of an observing subject
who is both the product and the site of certain practices, techniques, and
procedures of subjectification. The author’s playful interaction with the
print medium from _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ (1962) to _The Medium is the Massage_
(1967) and _War and Peace in the Global Village_ (1968) subtly reveals that
McLuhan’s tactile inscription on a page is not only correlated to changing
technologies and mechanical practices but to the changing forms of artwork and
representations. His juxtaposition of visual forms alerts the eyes and the
mind not to receiving pictures passively but to entering and reassembling them
actively, raising thus the question: Is typography in _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ a
device to intelligently intertwine figure and ground?

While Gutenberg’s fonts simulated the variety of handwriting, humanist
designers at the turn of the sixteenth century distanced the letter from
calligraphy by constructing roman alphabets with the tools of geometry. The
letterform was no longer thought as a sequence of manual strokes, but as a
conceptual ideal bound to no particular technology. By engaging the reader to
focus on perception rather than on interpretation, McLuhan favours sensation
over intellect, seeing over reading, and physical immediacy over social
mediation. Baudrillard noted the relationship between McLuhan’s comprehension
of the artistic role of typography and Walter Benjamin’s landmark essay “The
Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction” (1968). What Walter
Benjamin explored with his groundbreaking essay (and what McLuhan later
observed) is how the age of mass media means audiences can listen to or see a
work of art repeatedly and access new meanings each time. Benjamin and McLuhan
both grasped that the technique as a medium was the principle and stimulus for
a new generation of meaning. Both authors drew attention to the technique of
reproduction as a definitive aspect of modern culture, encouraging us to make
sense or nonsense today of the digital world. Such an approach engages us to
see the invisible effects of digital technologies and to connect them with the
visible effects of print, radio, and television on culture. It requires from
us the construction of intelligent imagery to test our understanding of
objects for which knowledge is still being built. Using plurimodal languages
to illustrate the shifts triggered by digital technologies on scholarly
publishing, or designing perceptual tools that can help the public understand
why research matters, is nonetheless as controversial today in the academic
world as it was in the early ’60s.

_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ design was indeed perceived “unorthodox” in the realm
of the university as publisher in 1962. With its bold copy decks and uneven
bottom margins, _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ stood outside the conventions of
acceptable book and scholarly publication design at the time. These
innovations though strongly aligned with the cut and thrust of McLuhan
epigrammatic style (Jeanneret 1989). Carl Dair, a member of the Society of
Typographic Designers (later the Graphic Designers of Canada) at the time,
supported Kurschenska’s work for _Galaxy_ , calling it “an important break in
the conventional book pattern.” Dair was convinced that only a few years would
be necessary for history to vindicate Kurschenska’s design. As it turned out,
it took only five years for the modernist development of publishing and design
to completely overtake Kurschenska’s modest innovations. Designs such as that
created for _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ pose thus important questions for design
history. What does design history achieve when it studies and celebrates
maximum innovation?

The history of modernism began as a renegotiation of visual traditions; new
visual experiences were made necessary by the effect of changing technologies.
Typesetters had to possess a sophisticated knowledge of design to “solve” the
various new layouts. Complex design would be left entirely to layout men such
as Kurschenska who worked in the typesetting and composition end of the
printing press. McLuhan, an ebullient young author when he wrote _The
Mechanical Bride: Folklore of Industrial Man_ , renegotiated meaning for the
new visual in the domain of academic publication. _The Mechanical Bride_ was
read then as an unconventional study of the nature and impact of public
communication via the mass media, including print advertising. For Jeanneret
(1989), McLuhan came at his thesis from perspectives that were novel,
imaginative, but often unconvincing. In the spring of 1961, when McLuhan
signed the contract for _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , and later in the autumn of
that year, when he strode into the University of Toronto Press office to
deliver the manuscript, Jeanneret did not fail to recognize it as unique when
he sent it over to Francess Halpenny with the following note:

I am not sure how far you have been into this yet, but I am certain you will
agree with me that it is at once exciting, wild, controversial, unconvincing
in places, utterly brilliant in others, etc. In short, I do believe that we
have here a book that holds the possibilities of being one of the most talked-
about and worthwhile works we have published in a long while. But I shudder to
think of the copy-editing that it requires, containing the proportion it does
of typos, quotations and citations, etc. The organization of chapter heads
alone is a mystery in my mind: I had a further word with the author and he
seemed to go along with the thought that chapters should run on, broken only
by his proposed sentence-long heads. It is fairly loaded with coined variants
of words, and the organization is certainly kaleidoscopic, to put it mildly
... Nevertheless, I think we should give this book everything we have (as I am
sure your department will). Just how much “finishing” the author can be
persuaded to face up to is hard to say; it could stand a vast amount. But I
think everyone concerned should be on guard against our selling this item
“short”; it could turn to be a landmark in our publishing programme, although
that may be an over-statement ... (Jeanneret 1989, 154)

To have labelled it a landmark publication was in no way an overstatement; it
was soon to be hailed as that across Canada and throughout the world. _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ , being as daring, edgy, and playful as it is, should
inspire scholars of the twenty-first century to design a post-Gutenbergian
model of knowledge and scholarly communication that does not entail
obliterating the past. In the twentieth century, the philosophical essay moved
further away from the ideas of the self, and became more self-conscious, in so
far as it is obsessed with language, discourse, and methodology. Whereas
McLuhan and Montaigne refused to separate themselves from the method, or to
distinguish the living subject from the experienced object in their essays,
the modern essay is no longer that of Montaigne’s times. Bound books such as
_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ have lived a charmed existence since typesetting was
invented in mid-fifteenth-century Mainz. This longevity makes me optimistic
about its evolutionary persistence in our imagination and way of seeing. As it
becomes more a virtual information space than a stable artefact, the
traditional volume of papers in between two covers will find another life,
another representation, as an interconnective environment integrating audio
and visual data that conceive and unfold stories of the digital era. Let’s
twist thus the kaleidoscope so that Renaissance and eighteenth-century spaces
of spectacles can gloss our current debates about digital scholarship where
data gathering can be aggregated via social media such as curated tweets.

The will to juxtapose a visual stratigraphy of artefacts can be traced back to
Giambattista Piranesi; his etching experimentation became one of the greatest
graphic innovations of the Renaissance, retrieved on walls, temples, baths,
and amphitheatres of the remains of a Rome that was no longer visible. The
power of Piranesi’s visual graphics arose from the collaging of complex
spatio-temporal events. This design to empower visual knowledge avoids
classificatory schemes based on similarity and linear sequence. McLuhan,
borrowing such a visual approach, asks the observer to make sense of material
that was not yet visible or understood (such as radio and television) when
_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ was published. Mimicking the juxtaposition typical of
the baroque, the staging of text, of words and blanks on the page, in _The
Gutenberg Galaxy_ and later in _The Medium is the Massage_ is like a mosaic
whose tesserae or meanings are simultaneously accessible to sight. Most of the
pages in _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ display visual blocks of texts where only the
placement of type indicates the change of authorship (see sample pages from
the original edition overleaf on [pages lvi](fm03.html#page_lvi) and
[lvii](fm03.html#page_lvii)). In _The Gutenberg Galaxy_ McLuhan demonstrates
his clear understanding of the laws of media and a trained awareness to make
sense of complex systems.

In the Enlightenment, powers of discernment and the development of probing
habits of sight were requisite skills. The understanding of elaborate three-
dimensional mosaic collages demonstrated how we learn and disseminate
knowledge by gathering, arranging, or juxtaposing bits and pieces. What can we
learn today from this collage of vignettes when the coalescence of image,
speech, print, performance is being enabled by the latest optical
instrumentation of the digital age?

Whether talking of then or now, it is fascinating to note that the reversion
of linear alphabetical or textual literacy into complex information and
seductive plurimodal tableaux is appealing to wider and diverse audiences. We
have witnessed the collapse of the mass literacy drives initiated during the
late eighteenth century. Pixels are our movable types. Manipulable images
continue to supplant directional narratives. The impulse to display and stage
information visually and acoustically though is still everywhere in evidence.
Mosaics of picture, word, and sound constitute playful artificial constructs
that are projected from electronic monitors and screens. The eighteenth
century witnessed the deconstruction of isolated genres and the stylish
collaging of disparate media, permitting everything to interact with
everything else. Just as the computer is both the tool and the metaphor for
today’s holistic approach to understanding creative processes, the “conquête
de l’ubiquité” (conquest of ubiquity) (Valéry 1964), optical apparatus, and
sensually direct demonstrations are the connective means spurring early modern
complexity research.

Borrowing McLuhan’s line, “The method of the twentieth century is to use not
single but multiple models for experimental exploration – the technique of the
suspended judgment” (_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ , 71), we should look at the
digital page by deconstructing the collaging of disparate media and make sense
of that disparity to test our judgment and our whole being as it is pitted
against the challenge of understanding the effect of digitality on our senses
and mind. There is no doubt that machine-generated images are extremely
mutable. If they can be misused, they will be. But that is not the fault or
purpose of the medium. What is at stake is the difficulty of separating forms,
genuine information from disinformation, when the material aspects of making
and the character of the maker are concealed or concealable. The Enlightenment
has taught us that within an increasingly phantasmagoric environment, images
have to be shown at work. The no longer evident relationship between the
complex form of input and the convergent form of output has to be deliberately
visually exposed. In our interactive age when potentially every individual can
influence political, social, cultural, and scientific decisions by simply
seizing the media, we need to transform raw data and information into meaning
and look for concrete ways to substantialize mediation. Reconnecting invisible
causes with the visible effects of digital technologies thus requires the
construction of intelligent imagery and a knowledge of complex systems.

Much of the Enlightenment’s understanding of complicated processes depended
upon dynamic and enlarged representations of tiny systems. The paradox posed
by complex and contradictory invisibles meant that illuminating metaphors had
to be drawn from supposedly better demarcated areas of study. Microorganisms
were illustrated and regarded as living grotesques. By their incongruity, they
startled the observer into paying attention to aspects of reality that could
be taken for granted or ignored. As McLuhan did, using analogy in an age of
difference and scrutinizing kinetics, shapes, patterns in which a coincidence
of opposites can be discerned will allow us to enter what was previously an
inaccessible reality. Since thinking involves scenography, the study of the
staging of a flow of perception and the warehousing of memories into the
spectacle of ideas should be aestheticized.

In pondering the mechanism of analogical thought, philosophers (chief among
them Plato, Aquinas, and Wittgenstein) admitted the coexistence of
incommensurable realms. They did not fragment them into cybernetic bits or
reproduce them ad infinitum with no hope of correlation. Ambiguity and
disproportion are inevitable between living things and their representation,
no matter how close the match. The transfer from a familiar to an unfamiliar
referent takes us to equivocal mindscapes. The difficulty is finding enough
similarity to warrant giving a common name to disparate items while
acknowledging their significant variations. Analogy, and the dynamic
equilibrium between figure and ground exploited by McLuhan as a method,
establishes a proportional relationship either among single items or among a
group of embodied properties existing under diverse conditions and adapted to
multiple purposes. Vision makes an imaginative leap; embarking on a
dialectical process of seeing affinities not easy to convey in words is what
challenges authors in the twenty-first century.

Scholars see writing as an extension of the body, as a supplement to the
capacity to speak; because writing is permanent rather than ephemeral, because
it withstands movements in place and time, and because it remains readable in
the absence of the author, design as touch needs to be reinvented for the
scholarly publication. The new understanding of the importance and qualities
of all aspects of visual communication may be the real historical origin of
design. We have come to see computers as driving innovation in design, but it
makes more sense to see them as popularizers or promoters, developing the
digital means to match the concepts of designers such as Kurschenska who
struggle against technology for the autonomy and pleasure of design. With
funding for book publishing becoming scarcer, scholars need to reinvent
meaningful partnerships with designers and artists, the way McLuhan did, to
convey in their essays the findings of their explorations. Pedagogical
programmes such as those designed by museums or architectural studies could as
well assist scholars to explore visual languages that translate what cannot be
effectively described in words. These multimodal spaces allow the scholar to
picture ambiguity in our age of blinding light. When considering the role
played by universities as publishers for _The GutenbergGalaxy_, we wonder then
what publishers can offer to scholars today. Like in the ’60s, making an
impact and making a profit are two different goals. For universities as
publishers the balance has to be maintained. Such questions are to be answered
as well by other organizations such as radio and television. What is the
future of radio on a mobile phone when distribution costs are higher on a
mobile? We do not have business models yet. Radio or print may just come in a
different form than what we know radio and television to be like. If podcasts
are still radio, what is the visual form of radio? Playing with words,
layouts, and visual forms is what McLuhan taught us to access in his print
material, and hence his continuing relevance in our understanding of digital
technologies and social media. We need to develop ways of seeing, to make use
of game play mechanics the way McLuhan did, and interact, body and mind, with
our own digital inscriptions and gestures.

_The Gutenberg Galaxy_ develops a mosaic or field approach to its problems.
Such a mosaic image of numerous data and quotations in evidence offers the
only practical means of revealing causal operations in history.

The alternative procedure would be to offer a series of views of fixed
relationships in pictorial space. Thus the galaxy or constellation of events
upon which the present study concentrates is itself a mosaic of perpetually
interacting forms that have undergone kaleidoscopic transformation –
particularly in our own time.

There might have been some advantage in substituting for the word “galaxy” the
word “environment.” Any technology tends to create a new human environment.
Script and papyrus created the social environment we think of in connection
with the empires of the ancient world. The stirrup and the wheel created
unique environments of enormous scope. Technological environments are not
merely passive containers of people but are active processes that reshape
people and other technologies alike. In our time the sudden shift from the
mechanical technology of the wheel to the technology of electric circuitry
represents one of the major shifts of all historical time. Printing from
movable types created a quite unexpected new environment – it created the
PUBLIC. Manuscript technology did not have the intensity or power of extension
necessary to create publics on a national scale. What we have called “nations”
in recent centuries did not, and could not, precede the advent of Gutenberg
technology any more than they can survive the advent of electric circuitry
with its power of totally involving all people in all other people.

The unique character of the “public” created by the printed word was an
intense and visually oriented self-consciousness, both of the individual and
the group. The consequences of this intense visual stress with its increasing
isolation of the visual faculty from the other senses are presented in this
book. Its theme is the extension of the visual modalities of continuity,
uniformity, and connectiveness to the organization of time and space alike.
Electric circuitry does not support the extension of visual modalities in any
degree approaching the visual power of the printed word.

The last section of the book, “The Galaxy Reconfigured,” deals with the clash
of electric and mechanical, or print, technologies, and the reader may find it
the best prologue.


## Prologue

The present volume is in many respects complementary to _The Singer of Tales_
